bestBHT.bht: Do not lie to one another, emphasizes the instruction, urging believers to completely abandon their old, unregenerate nature and its deceitful habits. Lying is recognized as a widespread fruit of sin that is prevalent where the gospel has not prevailed. The challenge is to align one's actions with their profession, acknowledging their connection as members of the same body, and rejecting lying as it contradicts their new identity and genuine expression of faith.

Henry Alford: Lie not unto (or towards: the lie is regarded as aiming in its direction at him to whom it is spoken) one another..." (Commentary)
Having put off the old man... with his deeds." (Commentary)
The old man... the nature which they had before their conversion." (Commentary)
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: unregenerate nature which ye had before conversion.
Albert Barnes: The reason for putting away lying...is, that we 'are members one of another' - or are brethren.
Lying is one of the fruits of sin.
The vice of lying is a universal fruit of sin, and seems to exist everywhere where the gospel does not prevail.
Marvin Vincent: Seeing that ye have put off [απεκδυσαμενοι] . See on ch. Colossians 2:15. The old man. See on Romans 6:6.
John Calvin: When he forbids lying, he condemns every sort of cunning, and all base artifices of deception.
The old man denotes — whatever we bring from our mother’s womb, and whatever we are by nature.
It is also to be noticed, that the old man is distinguished by his works, as a tree is by its fruits.
Philip Schaff: Lie not one to another. Comp. Ephesians 4:25. The practice of lying is referred to.
The old man with his deeds, or, 'practices;' the word usually having a bad sense in the New Testament (comp. Romans 8:13).
The 'flesh,' in its ethical sense, is here personified; see on Ephesians 4:22; comp. also Galatians 5:24: 'the flesh with the passions and the lusts thereof.'
Archibald T. Robertson: Lie not to another...It means either 'stop lying' or 'do not have the habit of lying.'"
Having stripped clean off...the old life of sin regarded as 'the ancient man' of sin already crucified and dropped now once and for all as a mode of life.
John Gill: Lie not one to another.... Which is another vice of the tongue, and to which mankind are very prone, and ought not to be done to any, and particularly to one another.
The saints are members one of another, and of the same body, which makes the sin the more unnatural.

Who is meant by the old man, and what by putting him off, and as for 'his deeds', they are the same with the deceitful lusts there mentioned, and the works of the flesh... Some... think that here is an allusion to the rite of baptism in the primitive church.

bhtAttempts.bht: Do not lie to one another, warns the verse. It calls believers to rid themselves completely of the old, unregenerate nature they had before their conversion, along with its deceitful habits of acting. This includes the vice of lying, which is a universal fruit of sin. The commentary suggests that the act of lying should be stopped altogether or not made into a habit. Followers of Christ are reminded that their practice must align with their profession, for they are members of the same body and lying is contrary to their new identity.

Do not lie to one another, warns the passage, emphasizing the need to abandon the deceptive habits of the old, unregenerate nature. This means putting an end to the widespread vice of lying that exists where the gospel does not prevail. Believers are called to align their practice with their profession, remembering that they are members of the same body. Lying is contrary to their new identity and the genuine expression of their faith.
